articles.title: Amelia E.H. Bridges
articles.description:
Postdoctoral Benthic Ecologist and National Geographic Explorer

amelia.bridges@plymouth.ac.uk or ameliabridges@hotmail.co.uk
articles.contents:
About me




I am a deep-sea ecologist with research interests broadly falling
into two fields: spatial ecology in the deep sea, and the use of science
to inform policy and marine spatial planning. I have investigated the
former both at broad- and fine-scales by employing predictive modelling
approaches.
I am particularly interested in how to best facilitate the use of
predictive model outputs in ocean policy to ensure ecosystem-based
management is based on best available data, and is possible for the deep
sea despite the general paucity of data.

My PhD




I completed my PhD, titled ‘Ecological Studies of the South
Atlantic Deep Sea to Inform Sustainable Management’, at the
University of Plymouth in the UK. This was in collaboration with the
Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Science (Cefas),
British Antarctic Survey (BAS) and the Norwegian Institute of Marine
Research (IMR).
My research focused on describing patterns in the ecology of
seamounts in the South Atlantic, linking these with environmental
parameters, and incorporating this baseline information into products
that support science-based decision making regarding management
regimes.

Key methodologies I employed included:
Uni- and multivariate statistical analysis of ecological data
(e.g. generalised additive models, general linear mixed effects models,
distance-based linear models, non-metric multidimensional scaling)
Habitat suitability modelling (HSM)
Broad-scale, non-hierarchical habitat classification

Life after PhD
I am now a Postdoctoral Research Associate at the University of
Plymouth, UK. My current research is part of the NERC-funded Seabed
Mining And Resilience To EXperimental impact (SMARTEX) project. My role
within this project is to develop larval dispersal models for deep-sea
taxa within the Clarion-Clipperton Fracture Zone (CCZ), the area in the
central equatorial Pacific where multiple mining licenses have been
awarded to companies and governments. Specifically, these are licenses
to mine polymetallic nodules which are small potato-sized deposits on
the seafloor that are rich in several important minerals. These nodules
provide hard substrate in an otherwise soft-substrate environment, and
hence support distinct faunal communities. The larval dispersal models
will help us to understand how areas within the CCZ are connected, and
further develop our understanding of what the future effects of deep-sea
mining might be on these fragile communities.
Aside from my main postdoctoral role, I am also actively engaged in a
number of other projects and programmes. These include Challenger 150, a
UN Ocean Decade Programme, where I am a member of the Central and South
Atlantic Regional Working Group, and the Deep Ocean Stewardship
Initiative (DOSI) where I am a member of the Fisheries Working
Group.
Since 2021, I have also undertaken some consultancy work. This has
included analysis of image data collected by the Joint Nature
Conservation Committee (advisers to the UK government) from the deep sea
to the north of Scotland, and contribution to reports focusing on areas
within the South Atlantic for Blue Marine Foundation.
Other academic interests




Science communication and public engagement has always been a passion
of mine, and in addition to my university-based and consultancy work, I
am heavily involved in local marine conservation around Cornwall in the
UK. I currently Chair the Looe Marine Conservation Group and act as
their Scientific Officer. Alongside our public engagement campaign where
we typically organise and run 30+ events per year ranging from guided
rockpooling to beach cleaning, our scientific projects include
monitoring of intertidal and subtidal habitats including rocky shores,
seagrass beds and oyster reefs. I have combined this passion with my
work at the University of Plymouth, enabling me to act as an external
supervisor for undergraduate, postgraduate and placement students.
